text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

Commonwealth Bank of Australia has drawn up a shortlist of two global providers of banking technology services - the Australian subsidiaries of US giants Electronic Data Systems and Computing Sciences Corp - to detail their strategies for the Bank's plan o outsource its core banking technology systems in a deal worth up to A$6 billion over 10 years. Page 1.

Despite its leadership among Australian corporations in employing women in high-level jobs, an area in which it has vastly outperformed any other bank, Westpac Banking Corp has suffered the loss of six of its top female executives in the past six months. Mary Carryer, the high-profile head of consumer marketing and product development, announced yesterday she will be leaving the bank when her contract ends in September. Page 1.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation Ltd yesterday unveiled the A$1.3 billion News Corp-EchoStar deal, which aims to create a new force in the fledgling US satellite television industry by merging its American Sky Broadcasting with rival EchoStar Communications Corp DISH.O. News is to outlay US$1 billion in cash and other assets for a 50 per cent stake in the alliance. Page 1.

After announcing yesterday that net profit in the six months to December had risen 57 per cent to A$61.3 million from A$39.1 million last year, industrial group Howard Smith Ltd revealed it will spend A$360 million fast-tracking the expansion of its succesful hardware retail chain. Page 21.

Arnotts managing director Chris Roberts revealed yesterday the company would be returning its biscuits to retail shelves, but said Arnotts faces losses of at least A$10 million after the extortion threat that led to the mass removal of its products from spermarket shelves in Queensland and New South Wales for the past 11 days. Page 21.

The 1996 Price Waterhouse Funds Management Industry Survey has revealed that only 41 per cent of participants are able to check whether they are complying with their investment management mandate when they are buying or selling a stock. The survey covers 7 major funds management organisations, which together account for A$140 billion of funds under management. Page 23.
THE AUSTRALIAN

News Corporation chairman and chief executive Rupert Murdoch announced yesterday a A$4.1 billion satellite joint venture with Colorado-based EchoStar Communications Corp. Murdoch said he expected News-EchoStar to win over 38 percent of the 21 million US houseolds expected to sign up for satellite pay TV. Page 21.

The Australian Securities Commission is alleging in the Federal Court that the London-based arm of broking giant Nomura International Plc was both the buyer and seller of securities in a manner calculated to create a false or misleading price for the shar price index futures contract last March 29, when A$600 million of futures and equities were sold in the closing minutes of trading. Page 21.

Shopping centre management group Westfield Holdings Ltd's profit rose almost 17 per cent from A$35 million to A$40.9 million in the December half year. The profit rise has boosted the interim share dividend, up three cents to 20.9 cents a share, while sales rose two per cent to A$275 million, but overall revenue slipped from A$320 million to A$310 million. Page 21.

A Price Waterhouse survey of 17 funds management companies has found investment in information technology must be lifted to allow companies to remain competitive and improve customer service. The A$280 billion funds management industry is under pressure from offshore competitors' low prices and product innovation. Page 21.

The Federal Court in Sydney heard yesterday that Optus Vision deliberately withheld from two per cent shareholder Seven Network Ltd details of a deal involving another shareholder Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd. Optus Vision feared Seven would leak the information to News Limited. In opening the case for the defence, Jeffrey Sher QC said there were reasons why Seven was excluded from the deal. Page 23.

Towage-to-retail conglomerate Howard Smith Ltd delivered a 57 per cent increase in interim net earnings due to improved earnings across most divisions, a lower tax rate and a A$14.4 million profit on the sale of one of its two remaining ships. Interim netprofit rose to A$61.3 million from A$39 million, with earnings for the second half expected to benefit from the sale of another ship as Howard Smith exits the shipping business. Page 23.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

In a deal which strengthens Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation's position in the new Direct Broadcast Satellite market in the United States, News has announcing a A$1.2 billion deal with US satellite television operator EchoStar DISH.O. The deal allows News to compete with free-to-air and cable TV operators by reaching an estimated 75 per cent of all households. Page 27.

After almost a year of investigation with the Australian Stock Exchange and the Sydney Futures Exchange, the Australian Securities Commission has commenced court action against global investment bank Nomura International for alleged market manipulation and misleading and deceptive conduct following a A$600 million stockmarket play last year. Page 27.

After delivering a 15.7 per cent rise in net profit to A$47 million in the six months to December, a result largely attributed to solid contributions from its BBC Hardware and Australian towage operations, engineering, hardware and towage group Howard Smith yesterday foreshadowed further growth in its full-year result. Page 27.

Jeff Sher QC told the Supreme Court yesterday the Seven Network could not be told of a secret deal between its fellow shareholders at Optus Vision because it was seen as a "Trojan horse" that would leak the deal's details to rival pay-TV operator Foxtel and its 50 per cent-owner News Corp. Page 29.

While announcing a 16.6 per cent increase in net profit to A$40.9 million for the six months to December, Westfield Holdings managing director David Lowy said retail sales in the giant shopping centre manager and developer's Australian centres were five pr cent higher in January compared with January 1996, heralding a revival in the country's ailing retail market. Page 29.

Speaking at a public hearing with the Productivity Commission, Toyota Australia president Sam Komori joined Ford's US chiefs in warning that Australia would lose its entire car industry if the Productivity Commission's proposal to slash tariffs to five percent by 2004 were accepted. Page 29.
THE AGE

Following the collapse of mediation talks, the Australian Securities Commission has launched Federal Court action against Nomura of Japan - one of the world's biggest brokers - alleging market manipulation and misleading and deceptive conduct over a A$600million trading operation 11 months ago. Page C1.

David Hwang, the managing director of Tuan Sing Holdings, which last month saved former stockbroker McIntosh Securities (now Merrill Lynch Australia) from a A$17 million potential liability related to the disastrous float of the Grand Hotel Group, is introducing the company to GHG's other substantial shareholders, explaining why a controlling interest in Melbourne's and Perth's Grand Hyatt hotels is such a good investment. Page C1.

The new Yellow Pages Small Business Index has revealed 80 percent of small businesses are disenchanted with the Howard Government, with more than one-fifth of business operators feeling the Coalition's policies are working against them. The Index comes out quarterly and this was the first in which negative sentiment towards the Federal Government outweighed the positive since Prime Minister Howard came to power last March. Page C1.

Diversified ferry operator Holyman is expecting new ferry route in Europe next month will make a major contribution to revenue in the current financial year. Holyman announced a net profit yesterday of A$21.86 million for the year ended 31 December, up frm A$16.09 million the previous year. Page C3.

Commonwealth Bank chief manager, group and corporate development, Lyndell Fraser confirmed that proposals had been sought from EDS Australia and CSC Australia with a view to forming a strategic information technology alliance. The Bank is poised to outsource its IT requirements in a deal that could be worth more than A$500 million a year and Fraser said CBA was initially seeking a partner to help develop its front-end systems. Page C3.

Westpac general manager, consumer marketing and product development Mary Carryer has resigned and will return to North America at the end of this year for personal reasons. The highly regarded Canadian banker developed award-winning banking products and mde considerable progress in improving Westpac's reputation as a retail bank. Replacing her will be DB Breweries general manager, marketing, Peter Maher. Page C3.
